snippet: To discharge student loans in bankruptcy, a borrower may have to convince a judge that life will never get better and destitution is certain.
abstract: Majority of those who declare bankruptcy do not even attempt to have their student loans erased, facing stiff federal laws that require them to convince a federal judge that there is a 'certainty of hopelessness' to their financial lives for much of the repayment period; Congress, in an effort to protect taxpayer money, has toughened laws related to forgiving student loans several times since the 1970s, even extending them to private loans in 2005 (Series: Degrees of Debt).
lead_paragraph: To discharge student loans in bankruptcy, a borrower may have to convince a judge that life will never get better and destitution is certain.
